It is well-known that if X is a scheme, then as a topological space it is sober and locally compact. However, it may fail to be quasi-separated or compact.
Let X be a scheme, U an open subset of X. Then (U,\mathcal {O}_{X}|_U) is again a scheme. There is a canonical inclusion U \hookrightarrow X. Morphisms of this form are called open immersion.

The disjoint union X \cong \coprod _{i\in I}X_i of arbitrary schemes is again a scheme. The structural sheaf on an open U is given by \mathcal {O}_{X}(U) \cong \prod _{i\in I}\mathcal {O}_{X_i}(U \cap X_i). They are indeed the coproducts in \mathbf {Sch}.

This way under Proposition , \Gamma \mathcal {O}_{\operatorname {Spec}\mathbb {H}[x]_+} \cong \mathbb {H}[x]_M \cong \mathbb {H}[x]. The final isomorphism is an easy exercise. This means the open immersion \operatorname {Spec}\mathbb {H}[x]_+ \hookrightarrow \operatorname {Spec}\mathbb {H}[x] induces an isomorphism on global section.
Let X be an image finite poset. Recall from Lemma that as a topological space it is locally spectral. It is a scheme.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: We need to define a structural sheaf on X. For any upward closed susbet U of X, we define \mathcal {O}_{X}(U) := \mathcal {U}(U), the distributive lattice of upward closed subsets of U. This is a sheaf, because if we have a union U = \bigcup _{i\in I}U_i with an element V_i \in \mathcal {O}_{X}(U_i), which is V_i \subseteq U_i upward closed, which agrees on intersections, V_i \cap U_j = V_j \cap U_i, then there is a unique V \subseteq U given by V = \bigcup _{i\in I}V_i, such that V \cap U_j = \bigcup _{i\in I}V_i \cap U_j = \bigcup _{i\in I}V_j \cap U_i = V_j \cap \bigcup _{i\in I}U_i = V_j \cap U = V_j. This is in fact a locally distributed space, because for any x\in X, \mathcal {O}_{X,x} \cong \mathcal {O}_{X}(\uparrow x) \cong \mathcal {U}(\uparrow x), which is local because \uparrow x has a root (cf. Remark ). Finally, this is a scheme, because by construction for any x\in X, the open neighbourhood \uparrow x is affine (\uparrow x,\mathcal {O}_{\uparrow x}) \cong \operatorname {Spec}\mathcal {U}(\uparrow x).

fr:title.text: A scheme is affine iff it is spectral

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: A scheme is affine iff it is spectral

fr:mainmatter.html:p: A scheme X is affine iff its underlying topological space is spectral, i.e. iff it is compact and quasi-separated.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Let X be a scheme whose underlying topological space is spectral. Let D be the distributive lattice of compact open subsets of X. Let \{U_i\}_{i\in I} be a finite family of affine open covers of X. For any U_i, since U_i is affine, and affine schemes are determined by their underlying topological space (see Remark ), we must have \mathcal {O}_{U_i} \cong D_i where D_i is the principle quotient of D corresponding to the compact open U_i. This way, \mathcal {O}_{X} and \mathcal {O}_{D} agree on this open cover, which implies that \mathcal {O}_{X} \cong \mathcal {O}_{D}.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: As a corollary of Theorem , if a scheme X is finite, then it is affine, since finite sober spaces are all spectral.
We say a map f : X \to Y between schemes is affine, if for all affine open \operatorname {Spec} A of Y, f^{-1}(\operatorname {Spec} A) is an affine open in X.

fr:title.text: Quasi-separated and separated schemes from morphisms

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Quasi-separated and separated schemes from morphisms

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Note that a scheme X is quasi-separated iff X \to 1 is quasi-separated, since the diagonal X \to X \times X is quasi-compact iff the intersection of quasi-compact opens in X is again quasi-compact. Hence, we also say X is separated if X \to 1 is separated.
A map f : X \to Y between schemes is (quasi-)separated, if the diagonal \Delta : X \to X \times _Y X is a closed immersion (quasi-compact).
We say a scheme is quasi-separated if its underlying topological space is quasi-separated.

fr:title.text: Characterisation of universally closed maps between schemes

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Characterisation of universally closed maps between schemes

fr:mainmatter.html:p:
The following are equivalent for a map f : X \to Y between schemes:
It is a universally closed map between schemes.
It is a universally closed map between topological spaces.
It is closed, and for any y\in Y the fibre f^{-1}(y) is quasi-compact in X.
It is quasi-compact and a q-map.
The equivalence (2) \Leftrightarrow (3) is from Proposition . (2) \Rightarrow (1) is evident.

To show (1) \Rightarrow (3), suppose f is a universally closed map between schemes. For any y\in Y, since pullback of schemes are topological (cf. Theorem ), it follows that f^{-1}(y) \to 1 must also be a universally closed map of schemes. By Proposition , f^{-1}(y) must be quasi-compact.
For (2) \Rightarrow (4), by a similar proof of Proposition one can show that f must be quasi-compact. It is a q-map because it is closed.

To show (4) \Rightarrow (1), it suffices to observe that if f is quasi-compact and a q-map, then by Lemma f must be closed; furthermore, both quasi-compactness (Proposition ) and q-maps (Lemma ) are closed under pullbacks, thus such maps are universally closed.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We say a map f : X \to Y between schemes is closed if as a map between topological spaces it is closed. We say it is universally closed if it is closed for arbitrary pullback of schemes.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: If P is a stalk local property, then for any scheme X, the property of affine open \operatorname {Spec} A with A satisfying P is affine local.

Let X be a scheme and x\in X. Then \operatorname {Spec}{\mathcal {O}_{X,x}} as a topological space is the subspace \uparrow x of X. Furthermore, this gives us a map \operatorname {Spec}{\mathcal {O}_{X,x}} \to X.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Let \operatorname {Spec} A be an affine open of x. Then x as a prime filter of A (cf. Remark ), \mathcal {O}_{X,x} \cong A/x. This way, the quotient A \twoheadrightarrow A/x induces the inclusion \operatorname {Spec}{\mathcal {O}_{X,x}} \to \operatorname {Spec} A \subseteq X. Verifying this does not depend on the specific choice of the affine open \operatorname {Spec} A is routine.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: On the level of set, \operatorname {Spec} A evidently factors through \operatorname {Spec}{\mathcal {O}_{X,x}} since as shown in Lemma the latter is \uparrow {x} = \uparrow {f(\bot )}, and f as a continuous map is in particular monotone. Then since at the level of stalks we have a t-conservative map f^{\sharp }_\bot : \mathcal {O}_{X,x} \to \mathcal {O}_{A,\bot } \cong A, this induces a map \operatorname {Spec} A \to \operatorname {Spec}\mathcal {O}_{X,x} which indeed when post-composed with the inclusion \operatorname {Spec}\mathcal {O}_{X,x} \to X gives us X. This can be seen easily when X is affine, and the general case is trivial from the proof of Lemma .

fr:title.text: Fibre products of schemes are topological

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Fibre products of schemes are topological

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let X,Y,S be schemes with morphisms f : X \to S and g : Y \to S. Then the pullback X \times _S Y exists in the category of schemes, and its underlying topological space is the pullback in the category of topological spaces.

The existence of the fibre products follows from the usual gluing argument for schemes in algebraic geometry, and reduces to the fibre products of affine schemes, which by Theorem are computed by spectra of tensor products.

To show the fibre products are topological, we first show this for affine schemes. In this case, the fibre products are computed by the spectrum of pushouts. The underlying set is the topological fibre products, because the points are computed by \mathbf {DL}(-,2), which takes pushouts to pullbacks. The topology also agrees due to our pushouts are concretely constructed as tensor product.
Now the general case for schemes follows from glueing.
More generally, we say a morphism f : Y \to X of schemes is quasi-compact, if the underlying continuous map is quasi-compact.

Let P be a property of morphisms of schemes. Then we say P is affine local on the target, if for any f : Y \to X, the property on affine opens \operatorname {Spec} A of X where the restriction f^{-1}(\operatorname {Spec} A) \to \operatorname {Spec} A satisfies P is affine local.

Let X be a scheme and let P be an affine local property on X. If there exists an affine open cover \{\operatorname {Spec} A_i\}_{i\in I} of X with each \operatorname {Spec} A_i satisfying P, then any affine open of X satisfies P.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Suppose we have an arbitrary affine open \operatorname {Spec} D of X. Since \operatorname {Spec} D is quasi-compact, we can cover \operatorname {Spec} D by finitely many \operatorname {Spec} A_i with each \operatorname {Spec} A_i satisfying P. Since standard opens of \operatorname {Spec} D form a basis, we can choose a generating family \{d_j\}_{j\in J} in D with \bigvee _{j\in J}d_j = 1, and each \operatorname {Spec} D/d_j is contained in some \operatorname {Spec} A_i. But since \operatorname {Spec} D/d_j is open compact in \operatorname {Spec} A_i, it can be identified as some \operatorname {Spec} A_i/a_j for some a_j in A_i. By assumption of P being affine local, each \operatorname {Spec} D/d_i satisfies P, hence \operatorname {Spec} D satisfies P.

We say a scheme is quasi-compact if its underlying space is compact.
A scheme X is integral, if it is non-empty, and for every non-empty open U of X, \mathcal {O}_{X}(U) is integral.

fr:title.text: Frame of opens of a general scheme

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Frame of opens of a general scheme

fr:mainmatter.html:p: For a scheme X, there is a bijective correspondence between its frame of opens and quasi-coherent ideals \mathrm {Idl}_Q(X) of X.

Again we prove a dual equivalence between \mathrm {Idl}_Q(X) and closed subsets of X. For any (quasi-coherent) ideal \mathcal {I} of \mathcal {O}_{X}, Construction gives us a closed subset C_{\mathcal {I}} already. Now for a closed subset Y of X, we construct an ideal \mathcal {I}_Y such that for any open U of X, \mathcal {I}_Y(U) := \{a\in \mathcal {O}_{X}(U)\mid \forall y \in Y \cap U.\ y \not \models a\}. This ideal is quasi-coherent, because if U is affine open \operatorname {Spec} A, then the intersection Y \cap \operatorname {Spec} A, in the notation of Proposition , is the closed set C_I for some ideal I of A. For any a\in A, \mathcal {I}_{Y}(\operatorname {Spec} A/a) = \{b\in A/a\mid \forall y \in C_I.\ y \not \models b\} = a \wedge I. By Proposition this means \mathcal {I}_Y is quasi-coherent.

Now if we start from a quasi-coherent ideal \mathcal {I}, to show \mathcal {I} = \mathcal {I}_{C_{\mathcal {I}}}, it suffices to show this on an affine open cover. For any affine open \operatorname {Spec} A of X, since C_{\mathcal {I}} \cap \operatorname {Spec} A is closed in \operatorname {Spec} A, it corresponds to C_I for an ideal I of A. Since \mathcal {I} is quasi-coherent, we must have \mathcal {I}(\operatorname {Spec} A) = \widetilde {I}. Hence, \mathcal {I}_{C_{\mathcal {I}}}(\operatorname {Spec} A) = \{a \in A\mid \forall y \in C_{\mathcal {I}} \cap \operatorname {Spec} A.\ y \not \models a\} = I = \mathcal {I}(\operatorname {Spec} A). This shows \mathcal {I}_{C_{\mathcal {I}}} = \mathcal {I}.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This is evident, since the condition exactly expresses that on each affine open \operatorname {Spec} A, \mathcal {I}|_{\operatorname {Spec} A} = \widetilde {\mathcal {I}(\operatorname {Spec} A)}.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let X be a scheme and C a closed subset of X. Let \mathcal {I} be the corresponding quasi-coherent ideal of \mathcal {O}_{X} as shown in Proposition . Then Construction makes C a scheme, with a closed immersion C \hookrightarrow X.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: The case when X is affine is clear. It is easy to see that when X = \operatorname {Spec} A and \mathcal {I} = \widetilde {I} for some ideal I of A, the closed immersion C_{\mathcal {I}} \hookrightarrow \operatorname {Spec} A is exactly \operatorname {Spec} I/A \hookrightarrow \operatorname {Spec} A induced by A \twoheadrightarrow I/A (cf. Remark ). The case for general schemes is then evident from this.
